Racist, as in deeply prejudiced against a person due to no factors beyond the color of their skin: Yes. Racist, as in perpetuating inherently unjust systems on them due to no factor beyond their skin color: Not in the US. Like a lot of “isms”, there’s both the personal and the systemic. One can be deeply and unfairly prejudiced against every person who has a factor of a different type of person. How that affects the person in question depends on where they are in particular social classes and hierarchy and just general systems of thought. My dad experienced anti-white racism as a child in the 1940’s, as he was one of the only white children in his school. He was targeted by both other children and adults for harassment and violence. However, he was not a victim of systemic racism - the majority culture in the United States was still geared towards him being the ideal. While he was lacking in a certain amount of power in his particular situation, all of the authority figures around the area were white, all of the heroes in pop culture were white, all of the presidents were white, and as he went to a Catholic school, all of the teachers were white. Everyone who was in charge of anything looked like him, and the people who looked anything like his classmates were mostly caricatures based on minstrel shows, aside from the odd black character in war movies. So, it’s complicated. My father experienced racist violence (he was stabbed three times and shot twice before he was in high school), but he ultimately benefited from systemic racism that said he was better than his peers because of his white skin, not because of his intelligence and drive. His intelligence and drive helped him get noticed, but he was noticed more easily than an equally gifted black boy would have been.

Any person can be prejudiced against members of any group. That is, anyone can pre-judge the members of a group, using stereotypical assumptions about the characteristics of a person unknown to them based solely on the person's membership in the group. The dictionary definition of “racism” may be indifferent to the power status of various groups, but keep in mind that dictionaries are usually written by members of the dominant group. The term “racism” was born of systematic attempts to subjugate people who have ancestry from continents other than Europe. The idea being that “whites” — people of European ancestry, especially northern European ancestry — are superior to all others. Members of the same group who brought the fictional concept of “race” into society also get to define the term “racism”, ignoring key elements of its history. That's convenient for whites. I know what it's like to feel hatred from blacks because I'm white. The fact is, I've always had the upper hand in those relationships because, as a white person, I've gone through life with the benefit of dominant group status. Most people pre-judge me to be intelligent, honest, and capable. My life has had painful struggles, but none of my struggles have been related to my European ancestry, unless you consider that, as research shows (see Crocker & Major, 1989), people of European ancestry in the US generally have lower self esteem than people of African ancestry, which may have put my white mother, who took her own life when I was a baby, and my white son, who overdosed on opiates at age 24, at greater risk for those outcomes. We have a perfectly good word for the pre-judging of whites, women, people with medical conditions such as obesity, the differently abled, and all other groups. That word is “prejudice”. The word “racism” would not exist without the bogus science cooked up to support the myth of European supremacy. It makes sense for dictionary publishers to account for the etymology of words as they define them, and usually they do. But in the case of the word “racism”, they chose to go the easier “both sides” route, leaving the crucial element of power/dominance out of the definition. This may change in time. You may have heard that a thing of importance within a particular culture may come with multiple words to refer to the thing and account for different qualities of said thing. For example, The Sami, who live in the far north of Norway, Sweden, Finland and Russia, have at least 180 words for snow. Each unique term for snow refers to a different kind of snow — fresh snow or icy snow or packed snow (See Alison Kroulek, K-International blog, 2015). In English, we have different words for prejudice. “Racism” is a particular type of prejudice used in the oppression of people who are descended, at least in part, from people with long histories on continents other than Europe. The only reason to take the role of power/dominance out of the definition of racism is to obscure the responsibility of white people in maintaining racist systems.

This is impossible to answer meaningfully until we agree on a shared working definion of “racist”, and on the geographical context where we are applying it. Some people (or some contexts) use the word to mean something like “hostile towards, or prejudiced against, others based just on their perceived race”, or “subscribing to a concept of racial superiority”, in which case one could certainly be racist against white people, so the answer is “yes” with that definition. Other people, more recently, use the word to mean “supporting an existing systematic heirarchy based on race”. In this usage, typically, it is by definition not possible to be racist against whatever the locally more powerful race happens to be. In the US, for example, that would be whites. Elsewhere, it can differ. So in this usage, the answer is “yes, but only in contexts where whites do not dominate the local society”. But the answer could be “no” when using the second definition and within a white-dominated society. (It’s hard not to at least briefly note here that the concept of “race” is complex in itself and likewise very semantically confused by differing definitions) Back to “racist”. Either usage can be internally consistent, and can make sense. Neither usage is more objectively “correct”. The second usage is more recent, and is more “prescriptive” (how somebody asserts the word SHOULD be used), the former is more descriptive (how most people - across the whole population of English speaker - actually use it today). We could leave this as an answer - that it depends on which definition you are using and potentially on the geographical location. But some people are insisting politically that they get to completely control the one and only “correct” meaning of the word, which from now on can have only that one second meaning worldwide. They not rarely like to “correct” anybody using the word in any other usage. Many find this approach both arrogant and unconvincing. The only way to have a meaningful conversation across political differences is to be explicit and a bit more humble about the working definitions, to find some common agreement as to what one means by “racist” or “racism” IN THE PRESENT CONVERSATION, setting aside which is “right definition” in any absolute sense, in favor of discussing the concepts rather than arguing about the labels. I often use “racially biased” or “racially prejudiced” as a race-neutral term which both sides understand more or less similarly. If one is talking about systematic power differences, then I might use “systematic racism”, which can be explained to both sides. Just using the unqualified terms “racist” or “racism” is a sure way to cause people to unwittingly talk past each other, or provoke a distracting and dysfunctional fight about control of language.

Yes. You can be part of a culture which constructs a racial epistemology that categorizes unique individuals into the arbitrary category of “white" and declares that nearly all, if not all, people of this category have common characteristics essential to their biological nature, which might or might not be mutable. That is racism. The prejudice + power/privilege model of racism has very little utility to most individuals, and is often used as a means to reconstruct rather than abolish the dominant racial epistemology. If, for example - hypothetically, a bunch of PoC started beating up white people in their neighborhood or school because they held a particular racial epistemology which lead them to the belief that white people are inherently and biologically predisposed to being oppressive and need to be tamed into becoming “human beings" through violence, then yes that is racism. That is the case regardless of this group not having power beyond their locality and collectivity in the greater society. When talking about structural racism the prejudice + power model makes sense. When talking about the interactions between localized collectivities and individualities it only makes sense in so much as structural racism has an influence on these collectivities and individualities, which is not some constant, but rather varies in degree. Probabilistically it is less likely that PoC are racist to white people though, and when they are --there are fewer extant structures to act on their racism. That is why racism from white people is treated more seriously. But as we progress further toward structural equality (in terms of wealth, positions of power, etc) we will likely treat racism from any person equally seriously. Who does what when, depends on their individual views on said structural equality between so-called races.

Certainly. However, because of the position of white people in American society (significant majority with long-standing economic, cultural and political power), specifically, racism against white people doesn’t have the same kind of negative effects on white people that racism by white people has on non-white minorities. But it does exist, by definition: If someone hates, or looks down on white people, solely because they are white — that’s racism against white people — by definition. And, like all racism - it’s simply in error. People are individuals - regardless of the melanin content of their skin - or, in the case of some of us — the lack thereof. That said, racism against white people seems less prevalent than racism by white people — which usually seems to be the case, in most societies: the people who are racist, or bigoted in other ways (against members of certain religions, or against immigrants from certain countries, etc.) - seem to almost always come from people in the powerful majority who have succumbed to dysfunctional thinking. You do find racism or other bigotry directed against the powerful majority - but it seems less common - presumably because minorities have more direct experience with a wider variety of people, and don’t make the mistake of negative generalization that is required for bigotry as much, or as often.

We don’t worry about racism towards white people in this country too much because, generally speaking, white people don’t suffer as a result of other people’s racism. Nobody is marching in the street because police target and kill white people more than they should. Nobody’s stopping white people on the street, demanding to see their papers, and hauling them away to a detention center if they can’t prove they’re not immigrants.
